@bscscan And... done! 

21 of our 2021-released features. 

Which of these are your favorites?
Which ones do you want us to build more on?
Which features unlisted here do you want Etherscan to build?

Let us know and Happy 2022 ğŸš€

@bscscan 21. Updated API Page

Last but not least: update of API docs and landing pages. 

A clear description of various API plans, comprehensive list of API endpoints, tutorials for getting started and more. 

Using the Etherscan API has never been easier! ğŸ’«

https://t.co/qW8Qsnr3vD

@bscscan 19. Transaction Navigation

The Transaction Details page received a cool update in November: users can navigate between transactions based on sender nonce. 

Cycling ğŸš´ through transactions became much easier.

https://t.co/S0n5v52O6W

@bscscan 18. More Transaction Actions

2021 saw us adding more Transaction Actions in the Transaction Details page. Details of pending swaps and NFT transactions were two key ones. 

Expect even more Transaction Actions this year!

https://t.co/UHq2cxebgl

https://t.co/wLvYuucXfU

@bscscan 15. IDM

IDM (Input Data Messaging) have been around in Ethereum for a long time. In October, we released a simple read-only ğŸ“– feature gathering these into chat form. 

Messaging is a key use-case of Ethereum wallets â€” expect to see more here this year!

https://t.co/E47zKiNn6F

@bscscan 13. Error Messages

Error Messages became an issue - phishers were abusing URLs in them to mislead users.

A release got pushed in September balancing user safety with censorship-free UX.

https://t.co/7o0lfVwQvN

Custom error messages came shortly after.

https://t.co/4n0BQ0UBuW

@bscscan 12. Transaction Decoder

Devs and degens looking to explore transactions in more detail directly on Etherscan became able to do so in August. 

Simply open up any transaction, click the â€¦ menu on the top right and select 'Transaction Decoder'.

https://t.co/BwRzNsPb5G

@bscscan 9. Flashbots/MEV Support

We played our part in bringing light to the MEV dark forest early on in April by labelling ğŸ¤–âš¡ï¸ Flashbots MEV tx and blocks.

https://t.co/m2S0ajHDup

We later showed the status of Flashbots Protect RPC ğŸ›¡ pending transactions.

https://t.co/AhvxceGxVA

@bscscan 7. Natspec Support

Users of Etherscan's Read & Write Contract tabs received a gift to end the year with: Natspec support in December. 

Smart contracts with embedded Natspec now have descriptions shown in both tabs âœï¸

https://t.co/PrlFPZIXPZ

@bscscan 6. ENS Name Tags

In May, we added ENS Name Tags for accounts that have set a primary (reverse) record for their ENS names. 

Users are now able to see their ENS names throughout the explorer!

https://t.co/xHvYTCXn7f

@bscscan 5. DEX Trading Pairs

DEX Tracker extended in September to show you trading pairs and price chart of any ERC-20 token on SushiSwap or Uniswap v2 & v3.

https://t.co/7gIgYfZ768

Find your way there by clicking the Chart button in any ERC-20 Token page! ğŸ“ˆ

https://t.co/oYXQ8K4vw0

@bscscan 3. EIP-1559 Support

Ethereum's fee mechanism had a major update in August 2021 with EIP-1559, introducing dynamic gas prices, flexible block sizes and fee burns ğŸ”¥

Etherscan supported it off the bat displaying base fees, burnt fees and a dashboard!

https://t.co/Fo7OskTOhp https://t.co/BTikqkPggf

@bscscan 2. 'Method' Column

The Method field introduced in March allows end-users to see at one glance what function was executed by a transaction. 

A 2021 crowd favorite âœ¨

https://t.co/wH4A6DLDBk

1. Explorer-as-a-Service ğŸ”

Etherscan's stable of block explorers expanded massively in 2021. @etherscan and @bscscan remain 2 of the top websites in the ğŸŒ On top of these two, we built out explorers for a total of 9 chains!

Check out the full list on https://t.co/FZSqRjIoFx https://t.co/C0uWlAak4y

To read the article on Medium, click here: 
https://t.co/lROxpNq0lw

Whether it be the year of the bull, the bear, the ape or the shiba, we just keep building ğŸ‘·â€â™‚ï¸

Chart ğŸ“ˆ button on ERC20 Token pages

Clicking it brings you to a DEX Tracker page involving that token - displaying overall & trading pair information, USD price chart and latest on-chain trades! https://t.co/for51g7GUF

If you face issues with your wallet or exchange account (such as an un-updated balance or error logging in), their support teams are better positioned to assist you.

Reach out to them for help, but beware of fake ğŸš« Twitter accounts impersonating them!
A block explorer allows you to search for any address or transaction on a blockchain, but it is read-only ğŸ“– - it cannot execute any transaction on your behalf.

You may think of a block explorer as both a blockchain search engine ğŸ” and a read-only bank account ğŸ¦

A search engine like Google allows you to search for any piece of data on the internet ğŸŒ, while a bank account allows you to view your own balance and transaction history.

Although you may view your address and its token holdings from a block explorer, the explorer does NOT ğŸ™… hold or manage the tokens inside your address or any other addresses on the blockchain. 

Block explorers also do NOT ğŸ™… handle or process transactions.

A block explorer gathers this info, decodes it and displays it in legible form ğŸ“–

When you view an address's token balance, transaction history or analytics, you are actually viewing an indexed version of that data ğŸ§ from the blockchain about that particular address.

What is a block explorer? ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ“

Public blockchains are transparent and decentralized. Anyone in the world may see every transaction, every address and every token on the blockchain... But! This data is not readily accessible or understandable for the casual user.
